Package sockets

Version 0.1 by Theo Weidmann licensed under MIT

The sockets package allows you to open TCP sockets to servers or to create a TCP server socket yourself.

The following is a very basic example of opening a TCP socket to make an HTTP request and print the first 140 characters of the response.

ğŸ¦ socket ğŸº ğŸ”·ğŸ“ğŸ†• ğŸ”¤www.emojicode.orgğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤80ğŸ”¤
ğŸ’¬ socket ğŸ“‡ ğŸ”¤GET / HTTP/1.1âŒrâŒnHost: www.emojicode.orgâŒrâŒnâŒrâŒnğŸ”¤

ğŸ¦ data ğŸº ğŸ‘‚ socket 140
ğŸ˜€ ğŸº ğŸ”¡ data

At the time of writing this, the above code would return something similar to:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: GitHub.com
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Last-Modified: Sat, 29 Oct 2016 11:54:03 GMT
Access-Control-Al

Here weâ€™ve an example of a minimal echo-server that listens on port 8728. The server simply sends back a copy of the data it received.

ğŸ¦ server ğŸº ğŸ”·ğŸ„ğŸ†• 8728

ğŸ” ğŸ‘ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ¦ clientSocket ğŸº ğŸ™‹ server
  ğŸ” ğŸ‘ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

Of course, the code above is very minimal and incomplete. For example, it can handle only one connection.

Classes

ğŸ„
ğŸ„ represents a socket that listens for clients on a given port.
ğŸ“
ğŸ“ represents a socket for communication between client and server.
